p.hi: In fact, with regard to all that Paul the tentmaker has to say about
, we ought to place ourselves as it were within S
Paul's own class, the artisan class of the Imperial age, and then feel the force of his words. They all become more life–like when restored to their original historical
v Deissmann 'Light from the Ancient East'. p. 313
Paul A study in Social and Religious History' emphasizes the unimportance of S

Paul in his own age. Yet in Hastings' Dictionary of the Bible, I read as follows:– 'The wealth of Paul's father we may fairly infer from the education given him: his occupation as a tentmaker is no disproof of this, for well–to–do Jews wisely taught their sons some handicraft'. I prefer to think of S. Paul as the only 'gentleman & scholar' in the Apostolic college, &,

, its most influential teacher: for even 'the Prince of the Apostles' learned from him. The admirable Deissmann exaggerates the certainly considerable contribution he has made to N v T [sic] studies, & his enthusiasm for the testimony of papyri and ostraca [sic] almost creates a 'bee in his bonnet'.
